moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf: Nc3 seems obligatory, but it is a speed game.  A pawn may be worth taking someone out of their repertoire.
moves.12. Qd1 Be6 13. Ne4 Bxh6 14. Bxf6: I think the knight take was better as it delivers check.  He ends up saving both queen and rook by delivering check himself.
moves.14... Qa5+ 15. Nd2 Rg8 16. O-O: Despite his advantage in rating, or perhaps because of it, the knight seemed a small price for king safety.
moves.22. Qxf4 Ne2+: Required as exf4 hangs the knight and would bring me back in the game.
moves.23. Kh1 Nxf4: We are beginning the unsound play area.
moves.24. Bxb7 Rb8: I should have considered that before attacking the pawn.
moves.25. g3: I cannot save both the b2 pawn and bishop, and I would like to open the e file anyway.
moves.25... Nh5 26. Bxe5 dxe5 27. Bd5: I would love to play a rook to e and take the pawn, but such a bold move would probably be prompt a more serious look at where I would like to attack.
moves.30. Bxg8 Nxg8: This is not perfect, but it may take some time for his knight to come back into play.
moves.33... Rc8 34. Re5+ Kf7 35. Rd1 Bc6 36. K: Perhaps not immediately necessary as 3e+ forces the move and the pawn cannot easily be supported.
moves.43... Ke6 44. Rc6+ Kd7 45. Rc5 Rb2: I think this move allows a non-win.
moves.46. Rd5+ Kc7 47. Rc5+ Kb7 48. Rb5+ Kc7 4: and I should have claimed the draw by threefold repitition here; he continues to play his king along the 7th rank except for e7.
moves.52... Kc7 53. Rc5+: I offered a draw.  I have a difficult time in play knowing exactly how many times a position has been repeated, so I figured he would just accept.
